comment: How many times have we all seen, in books on the middlegame or in annotated GM games, examples of severe weaknesses, such as Pd6, leading to a decisive game result? In this case Black has a bad weakness, but has also exchanged a couple of minor pieces, so that he's not terribly cramped. If Black had another weakness he might lose, but with only the one he's got a decent chance of drawing.
reasoning: The comment offers a relevant analogy and analysis of a potential tactical flaw, suggesting a strategic vulnerability that could lead to a loss.
